prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe CO (2-1) line with FDM mode, 1875 MHz baseband (2457 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976MHz (1.28 km/s) to sufficiently model the dynamics around the central massive object. This covers an entire velocity width expected from our single dish (APEX) observation (Davis et al. in prep.).
As discussed earlier, the error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).
We also include three continuum spectral windows in order to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

This galaxy has a known velocity dispersion value of 146.5 km/s (van den Bosch et al., submitted), which enable us to estimate the SMBH mass to be 3.6e7 solar mass by using M_BH-sigma relation (McConnell & Ma 2013). The sphere of influence (SOI) radius (r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2 where sigma is the central velocity dispersion), which is often considered to be an indicator of the SMBH mass detection (Ho et al. 2002), is thus calculated to be 0''.11 with a known distance to this object. In order to make sure that we can resolve the SOI, we propose the angular resolution to be around half of the SOI radius, so to be 0''.06, which can be achieved with C36-7 configuration at Band 6.
The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is 0''.65, smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk, expected from the dust structure seen by HST, 7'' (see Figure 2). We need to image larger angular structure in order to properly model the kinematics driven from the stellar mass distribution (see Figure 3). We thus propose for lower resolution track for the same object (see Science Goal 6).

We propose to detect the CO(2-1) emission line for the known flux 4000 (mJy/chan) and 500 (km/s) velocity width, observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.). By expecting the emission to be spatially resolved along the kinematical minor axis of the galaxy, we take the number of synthesized beams across the prominent dust structure observed with HST (see Figure 2) to determine the molecular gas extent to be 7''. We thus assume the observed flux per channel will be split in these beams to give us the expected surface brightness per beam.
Required rms noise level is calculated to be 4.8 mJy/beam for 3 sigma with the beamsize of 0''.06, which is around half of the estimated black hole sphere of influence (SOI, r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2, see Ho et al. 2002) for this galaxy, 0''.11. See below for the detailed calculation of the SOI radius. Given that the integration time does not change, we drop the rms noise level to 1.0 mJy/beam, which is still equivalent to 6.5 K and will be done within 11 minutes integration.
The error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. Observations thus require a high velocity resolution for our project. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).

We propose to observe CO (2-1) line with FDM mode, 1875 MHz baseband (2457 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976MHz (1.28 km/s) to sufficiently model the dynamics around the central massive object. This covers an entire velocity width expected from our single dish (APEX) observation (Davis et al. in prep.) and PdBI observation (Crocker et al. 2011).
As discussed earlier, the error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).
We also include three continuum spectral windows in order to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

The sphere of influence radius (r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2 where sigma is the central velocity dispersion), which is often considered to be an indicator of the SMBH mass detection (Ho et al. 2002), for this galaxy can be calculated to be 0''.57 by using following values: Measured SMBH mass using stellar kinematics, 8.3e8 solar mass, Krajnovic et al. 2009. Central velocity dispersion of 244 km/s, van den Bosch et al. submitted known redshift-independent distance from NED, 23.3 Mpc.
In order to make sure that we can resolve the SOI, we propose the angular resolution to be around half of the SOI radius, so to be 0''.3.
The largest angular scale for the molecular disk extent of this object is 10'' (Croker et al. 2011, see Fig. 2), which makes the 12m-extended observation of 1.2 hours (including 25 minutes calibration) and 12m-compact observation of 36.27 minutes (including 12.34 minutes calibration), calculated by the Observing Tool.

We propose to detect the CO(2-1) emission line at 3 sigma for the known flux 50 (mJy/chan) and 465 (km/s) velocity width, observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.). This galaxy has been observed with PdBI with low resolution (Crocker et al. 2011, see Fig. 2), and the known molecular gas extent is 7'' at CO(1-0). By expecting the emission to be spatially resolved along the kinematical minor axis of the galaxy, we take the number of synthesized beams across the minor-axis length 7''. We thus assume the observed flux per channel will be split in these beams to give us the expected surface brightness per beam.
Required rms noise level is calculated to be 0.5 mJy/beam with the beamsize of 0''.3, which is around half of the estimated black hole sphere of influence (SOI, r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2, see Ho et al. 2002) for this galaxy, 0''.57. See below for the detailed calculation of the SOI radius.
The error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. Observations thus require a high velocity resolution for our project. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).

We propose to observe CO (2-1) line with FDM mode, 1875 MHz baseband (2457 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976MHz (1.28 km/s) to sufficiently model the dynamics around the central massive object. This covers an entire velocity width expected from our single dish (APEX) observation (Davis et al. in prep.).
As discussed earlier, the error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).
We also include three continuum spectral windows in order to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

This galaxy has a known velocity dispersion value of 214 km/s (LEDA database), which enable us to estimate the SMBH mass to be 3.1e8 solar mass by using M_BH-sigma relation (McConnell & Ma 2013). The sphere of influence (SOI) radius (r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2 where sigma is the central velocity dispersion), which is often considered to be an indicator of the SMBH mass detection (Ho et al. 2002), is thus calculated to be 0''.13 with a known distance to this object. In order to make sure that we can resolve the SOI, we propose the angular resolution to be around half of the SOI radius, so to be 0''.06, which can be achieved with C36-7 configuration at Band 6.
The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is 0''.65, smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk, expected from the dust structure seen by HST, 8'' (see Figure 2). We need to image larger angular structure in order to properly model the kinematics driven from the stellar mass distribution (see Figure 3). We thus propose for lower resolution track for the same object (see Science Goal 7).

We propose to detect the CO(2-1) emission line for the known flux 1800 (mJy/chan) and 400 (km/s) velocity width, observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.). By expecting the emission to be spatially resolved along the kinematical minor axis of the galaxy, we take the number of synthesized beams across the prominent dust structure observed with HST (see Figure 2) to determine the molecular gas extent to be 8''. We thus assume the observed flux per channel will be split in these beams to give us the expected surface brightness per beam.
Required rms noise level is calculated to be 4.5 mJy/beam for 3 sigma with the beamsize of 0''.06, which is around half of the estimated black hole sphere of influence (SOI, r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2, see Ho et al. 2002) for this galaxy, 0''.13. See below for the detailed calculation of the SOI radius. Given that the integration time does not change, we drop the rms noise level to 1.0 mJy/beam, which is still equivalent to 6.5 K and will be done within 11 minutes integration.
The error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. Observations thus require a high velocity resolution for our project. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).

This covers an entire velocity width expected from our single dish (APEX) observation (Davis et al. in prep.).

We also include three continuum spectral windows in order to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

This galaxy has a known velocity dispersion value of 202 km/s (LEDA database), which enable us to estimate the SMBH mass to be 2.2e8 solar mass by using M_BH-sigma relation (McConnell & Ma 2013). The sphere of influence (SOI) radius (r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2 where sigma is the central velocity dispersion), which is often considered to be an indicator of the SMBH mass detection (Ho et al. 2002), is thus calculated to be 0''.12 with a known distance to this object. In order to make sure that we can resolve the SOI, we propose the angular resolution to be half of the SOI radius, so to be 0''.06, which can be achieved with C36-7 configuration at Band 6.
The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is 0''.65, smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk, expected from the dust structure seen by HST, 10'' (see Figure 2). We need to image larger angular structure in order to properly model the kinematics driven from the stellar mass distribution (see Figure 3). We thus propose for lower resolution track for the same object (see Science Goal 8).

We propose to detect the CO(2-1) emission line at 3 sigma for the known flux 550 (mJy/chan) and 600 (km/s) velocity width, observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.). By expecting the emission to be spatially resolved along the kinematical minor axis of the galaxy, we take the number of synthesized beams across the prominent dust structure observed with HST (see Figure 2) to determine the molecular gas extent to be 10''. We thus assume the observed flux per channel will be split in these beams to give us the expected surface brightness per beam.
Required rms noise level is calculated to be 0.9 mJy/beam for 3 sigma with the beamsize of 0''.06, which is around half of the estimated black hole sphere of influence (SOI, r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2, see Ho et al. 2002) for this galaxy, 0''.12. See below for the detailed calculation of the SOI radius.
The error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. Observations thus require a high velocity resolution for our project. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).

We propose to observe CO (2-1) line with FDM mode, 1875 MHz baseband (2457 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976MHz (1.28 km/s) to sufficiently model the dynamics around the central massive object. This covers an entire velocity width expected from our single dish (APEX) observation (Davis et al. in prep.).
As discussed earlier, the error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).
We also include three continuum spectral windows in order to accurately measure and remove any continuum emission present.

This galaxy has a known velocity dispersion value of 188 km/s (LEDA database), which enable us to estimate the SMBH mass to be 1.5e8 solar mass by using M_BH-sigma relation (McConnell & Ma 2013). The sphere of influence (SOI) radius (r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2 where sigma is the central velocity dispersion), which is often considered to be an indicator of the SMBH mass detection (Ho et al. 2002), is thus calculated to be 0''.11 with a known distance to this object. In order to make sure that we can resolve the SOI, we propose the angular resolution to be around half of the SOI radius, so to be 0''.06, which can be achieved with C36-7 configuration at Band 6.
The largest angular scale visible in this array configuration is 0''.65, smaller than the total extent of the molecular disk, expected from the dust structure seen by HST, 3'' (see Figure 2). We need to image larger angular structure in order to properly model the kinematics driven from the stellar mass distribution (see Figure 3). We thus propose for lower resolution track for the same object (see Science Goal 9).

We propose to detect the CO(2-1) emission line at 3 sigma for the known flux 120 (mJy/chan) and 480 (km/s) velocity width, observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.). By expecting the emission to be spatially resolved along the kinematical minor axis of the galaxy, we take the number of synthesized beams across the prominent dust structure observed with HST (see Figure 2) to determine the molecular gas extent to be 3''. We thus assume the observed flux per channel will be split in these beams to give us the expected surface brightness per beam.
Required rms noise level is calculated to be 1 mJy/beam for 3 sigma with the beamsize of 0''.06, which is around half of the estimated black hole sphere of influence (SOI, r_SOI=G*MBH/sigma^2, see Ho et al. 2002) for this galaxy, 0''.11. See below for the detailed calculation of the SOI radius.
The error of the measured SMBH mass will be directly affected by the channel width. Observations thus require a high velocity resolution for our project. We propose the bandwidth for sensitivity, to be 15 km/s, which is estimated to be the ideal channel width to balance the integration time and the ability to detect SMBH mass (Davis 2014).

We request an identical frequency set-up to our higher resolution track (Science Goal 1, C36-7 configuration), so that the data will be easily combined. As in Science Goal 1, we request to cover the CO(2-1) line width observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.) by using FDM mode, 1875 MHz baseband (2457 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976MHz (1.28 km/s). We bin the data with the channel width of 15 km/s to match the high resolution track for the same object.
We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies in order to accurately model and subtract any continuum emission present.

The largest angular scale attainable with C36-7 configuration, 0''.65, was smaller than the expected total extent of the molecular disk in this object (see justification in Science Goal 1). From the velocity field analysis simulation (see Figure 3), we propose to observe larger structure to distinguish SMBH mass and stellar mass from the kinematics. We therefore choose C36-3 configuration for this science goal at Band 6, which serves 0''.5 resolution as the smallest beam size, by which means it can fill in the uv plain. The largest angular size for this configuration (10.9) exceeds 7, which is the estimated extent of this source (see Figure 2).

We aim to obtain an intermediate resolution image for NGC4501 so to combine with high-angular resolution image. We match the expected peak emission and required sensitivity with the C36-7 configuration observation for the same galaxy. In order to assure the data will be easily combined with the higher-angular resolution image (Science Goal1), we request the same surface brightness limit, correlator setup, and channel width.
We note that the requested RMS for this source can be achieved within 10 seconds of integration, but the total integration time is set to be 2 minutes by the ALMA Observing Tool, making the whole observation into 22.6 minutes including the overhead.

We request an identical frequency set-up to our higher resolution track (Science Goal 3, C36-7 configuration), so that the data will be easily combined. As in Science Goal 1, we request to cover the CO(2-1) line width observed with APEX (Davis et al. in prep.) by using FDM mode, 1875 MHz baseband (2457 km/s) and a raw spectral resolution of 0.976MHz (1.28 km/s). We also include three continuum spectral windows at higher frequencies in order to accurately model and subtract any continuum emission present.

We therefore choose C36-3 configuration for this science goal at Band 6, which serves 0''.5 resolution as the smallest beam size, by which means it can fill in the uv plain. The largest angular size for this configuration (10''.9) exceeds 8'', which is the estimated extent of this source (see Figure 2).

We therefore choose C36-3 configuration for this science goal at Band 6, which serves 0''.5 resolution as the smallest beam size, by which means it can fill in the uv plain. The largest angular size for this configuration (10''.9) exceeds 3'', which is the estimated extent of this source (see Figure 2).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Black holes are considered to play an important role in the galaxy evolution process, leading to various known correlations between the mass of the supermassive black hole (SMBH) and host galaxy properties. The correlations, however, are based on a relatively small number of measurements and a handful of methods with some limitations on sample selection. Our recent work on NGC4526 with CARMA and on NGC1097 with ALMA Cycle 0 has shown the SMBH mass estimation by tracing the rotation of molecular gas disks in the galaxy centre with high angular resolution. This new method expects the number and variety of accurate SMBH masses to increase in the ALMA era. ALMA Cycle 3 enables one to measure SMBH mass in some nearby galaxies by utilizing extended array configuration. We propose to observe 5 galaxies accross the Hubble sequence: NGC0524 (SA0), NGC4501 (SAb), NGC5064 (SAa), NGC6753 (SAb), and NGC6958 (cD), all of which are expected to show the SMBH-driven kinematics at relatively large apparent radius. The data will allow us to weigh SMBHs using molecular gas at various types of galaxies, and to cross check our method for NGC0524, which has its SMBH mass measured with stellar kinematics.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Project Code=2015.1.00419.S, PI=Timothy Davis, "WISDOM: Extending black hole demographics across the mass-size plane with ALMA" Project Code=2015.1.00598.S, PI=Martin Bureau, "WISDOM: CO Imaging of SMBH Mass Measurement Candidates"
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Weighing Supermassice Black Holes with ALMA , Project Code=2013.1.00493.S, PI=M. Bureau
